channel.title: NIO Framework
channel.description:
NOTE: THIS IS NOT MINE
NIO Framework - a.k.a ~ new input output Made out from scratch following a tutorial No pictures, why? Because it's not finished.
- Contains;
[ul][li]Server[/li] [li]Event[/li] [li]EventImpl[/li] [li]EventListener[/li] [li]EventManager[/li] [li]Logger[/li] [li]ConnectionListener[/li][/ul] This is a basic NIO Framework, with shitty codes, which provides a mechanism for non blocking I/O. I've looking around the classes, been working with the shitty codes, and I just decided to switch to xSocket, and since I'm kinda new to working with Frameworks I've decided that that would be the best solution. The Framework was started and finished in an IDE, and has a good package.
I don't know if this will be useful to you, I'm just contributing, since I don't need this.. And as I see and know, 80% of them which are going to check this out won't know what's this about..
[url=http://uppit.com/01kyn7uqu7td/NIO_framework.rar]Download Link[/url]

item.title: NIO Framework
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Release your work and your work only, releasing something made straight from a tutorial isn’t ok.

Read full topic

item.title: NIO Framework
item.dc:creator: @I_Roll_Deep I Roll Deep
item.description:
@I_Roll_Deep wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:10, topic:414893”][quote author=I Roll Deep link=topic=516855.msg3753441#msg3753441 date=1316227075]
BECAUSE I HAD IT FUCKING OPENED IN MY ECLIPSE, THINK BEFORE YOU WRITE SOMETHING .
[/quote]

Just opening it in eclipse wouldn’t modify it. Like I said, it is in there from creation[/quote]
Okay, I’ll tell this to you once again. This isn’t mine. This has been created from “scratch” following a tutorial. By looking on the codes, I’ve realized it was shit, I’ve decided to release this because someone could find it “useful”.
The tutorial can be found at R-S. Made by `White. Why was I following that tutorial? Because I’m fucking new to frameworks and I want to know a damn

Read full topic

item.title: NIO Framework
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

I Roll Deep:

BECAUSE I HAD IT FUCKING OPENED IN MY ECLIPSE, THINK BEFORE YOU WRITE SOMETHING .

Just opening it in eclipse wouldn’t modify it. Like I said, it is in there from creation

Read full topic

item.title: NIO Framework
item.dc:creator: @I_Roll_Deep I Roll Deep
item.description:
@I_Roll_Deep wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:7, topic:414893”][quote author=I Roll Deep link=topic=516855.msg3753412#msg3753412 date=1316226128]

[code]/**
* i equals to keys iterator
*/
Iterator<?> i = keys.iterator();

			/**
			 * iterator has next
			 */
			i.hasNext();
			
			/**
			 * the key is equal to iterator next
			 */
			SelectionKey key = (SelectionKey) i.next();[/code]

You’re only handling one key per select… Way to go :f

[hr]
You accept a connection, but don’t actually update the operations you’re interested in.
You don’t need to allocate a new buffer every time something needs to be read.

And your “event” system confuses the hell out of me. Why is it even there?

This is not mine.
[/quote]

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <classpath> <classpathentry kind="src" path="src"/> <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER/org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.launcher.StandardVMType/jre6"/> <classpathentry kind="lib" path="/Osiris/trunk/lib/slf4j-api-1.5.8.jar"/> <classpathentry kind="output" path="bin"/> </classpath>

Then why would you have slf4j in your classpath from Osiris? Eclipse will not modify that unless you manually add it (Which isn’t needed for this project) so it is there from project creation.[/quote]
BECAUSE I HAD IT FUCKING OPENED IN MY ECLIPSE, THINK BEFORE YOU WRITE SOMETHING .

OmgItsShane:

Holy shit. Your rolling deep. Another great release from teh only I ROLL DEEEEEEEP

Thanks babe

Read full topic

item.title: NIO Framework
item.dc:creator: @OmgItsShane Shane
item.description:
@OmgItsShane wrote:

Holy shit. Your rolling deep. Another great release from teh only I ROLL DEEEEEEEP

item.title: NIO Framework
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“I Roll Deep, post:5, topic:414893”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=516855.msg3753376#msg3753376 date=1316224335]

[code]/**
* i equals to keys iterator
*/
Iterator<?> i = keys.iterator();

			/**
			 * iterator has next
			 */
			i.hasNext();
			
			/**
			 * the key is equal to iterator next
			 */
			SelectionKey key = (SelectionKey) i.next();[/code]

You’re only handling one key per select… Way to go :f

[hr]
You accept a connection, but don’t actually update the operations you’re interested in.
You don’t need to allocate a new buffer every time something needs to be read.

And your “event” system confuses the hell out of me. Why is it even there?
[/quote]
This is not mine.[/quote]

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <classpath> <classpathentry kind="src" path="src"/> <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER/org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.launcher.StandardVMType/jre6"/> <classpathentry kind="lib" path="/Osiris/trunk/lib/slf4j-api-1.5.8.jar"/> <classpathentry kind="output" path="bin"/> </classpath>

Then why would you have slf4j in your classpath from Osiris? Eclipse will not modify that unless you manually add it (Which isn’t needed for this project) so it is there from project creation.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:

[code]/**
* i equals to keys iterator
*/
Iterator<?> i = keys.iterator();

			/**
			 * iterator has next
			 */
			i.hasNext();
			
			/**
			 * the key is equal to iterator next
			 */
			SelectionKey key = (SelectionKey) i.next();[/code]

You’re only handling one key per select… Way to go :f

[hr]
You accept a connection, but don’t actually update the operations you’re interested in.
You don’t need to allocate a new buffer every time something needs to be read.

And your “event” system confuses the hell out of me. Why is it even there?

@I_Roll_Deep wrote:

NOTE: THIS IS NOT MINE

NIO Framework - a.k.a ~ new input output
Made out from scratch following a tutorial
No pictures, why? Because it’s not finished.

  • Contains;

[ul][li]Server[/li]
[li]Event[/li]
[li]EventImpl[/li]
[li]EventListener[/li]
[li]EventManager[/li]
[li]Logger[/li]
[li]ConnectionListener[/li][/ul]
This is a basic NIO Framework, with shitty codes, which provides a mechanism for non blocking I/O.
I’ve looking around the classes, been working with the shitty codes, and I just decided to switch to xSocket, and since I’m kinda new to working with Frameworks I’ve decided that that would be the best solution.
The Framework was started and finished in an IDE, and has a good package.

I don’t know if this will be useful to you, I’m just contributing, since I don’t need this…
And as I see and know, 80% of them which are going to check this out won’t know what’s this about…
